This is a good company, but I do see a problem here. If you just look a the balance sheet, the amount of debt they have just keeps going up considerable as they build more and more inventory of housing. That's great if the housing boom continues, but it's not if we have a crash in housing like in 2007.

I hope we don't get that blow out qtr and trades down. BUT it would be time to LOAD UP the TRUCK if it does. I don't think it ran up to much before earning. All about the outlook they low balled outlook last qtr and WS knows it. UNDER PROMISE and over deliver, OK with me.

Earnings will come out in about 3 weeks. Here is a preview.Total revenue will be a bit north of $790 million. with EPS of $4.24/share. (maybe as high as $4.44). They might not raise guidance but it will be pretty transparent that they are sandbagging if they do not. They closed over 950 homes per month last Q and to beat the high end of guidance they only need to sell 820 per month. For the year it is clear to me that they will sell something north of 11,000 homes probably 11,300-11,500. Revenue will be almost 3.2 billion $150 million above the high estimate) and EPS will be $17.50 or more assuming those closings.I am assuming price increases will slow if they do not profits could be higher. If my projections are correct we are selling at 9X Earnings per share. With our growth pattern and ROI I would say we should normally get about a 13X multiple in this very cyclical business where multiples are usually much lower than the market as a whole. 13X gets us a price of $227. Pretty soon the market will start taking into consideration 2022 earning projections so we could conceivably see this touch 250-260 before the end of the current quarter.

I think that this quarters sales growth is about 13% above on year ago --with 1052 sales vs 934 -- please correct me if I am wrong. That is not a good number, but what do I know? Back when they were growing 25% plus each quarter the stock was stuck at a very low price but quite volatile. Now it seems be steadily increasing in spite worsening numbers. I am not short the company and am a long term positive but my wrong thinking made me imagine I might buy in at a much lower price with these numbers. Still, unless their margins increased a lot, or they somehow raise forward earnings, this quarter's report is going to be a miss (sales growth slowing) and I think I can buy shares below 30 -- we'll see. Also pretty certain rates will rise with next Fed meeting and yet that might be good for a company who sells lower priced homes. Just my thoughts as I am trying to use some logic to make money in this company. If it is a sector issue -- I would imagine the whole Home-builder stocks will start sinking as rates have to begin going up in the next few years.

LGIH seems like a no-brainer to me at these prices. They are in a demographic sweet spot (first time buyers looking for low cost entry), and have performed amazingly well over time. Three new Communities announced in the last week! I guess some people may be spooked by the possibility of higher interest rates, but they should affect LGIH the least considering that it offers lower bracket prices. The apparently large short position, according to my understanding, is largely the result of hedging by holders of convertible debt and, to that extent at least, does not represent a bet against the company's future. The convertibles are close to conversion parity, and in any case mature in two or three years, so they won't be a factor too much longer.

not sure anyone uses yahoo board anymore -- but I have had interesting info from other investors in the past -- so I'll give it a try. Last 2 months sales reports seem tepid -- down in July and up 19% in August from one year ago figures. To continue at 20% growth they needed to sell ??? 530 homes in Sept. -- seems doubtful. I am guessing the number is leaked out and maybe that explains some selling today. A short term disappointment might cause the stock to drop back into the high 20's. Long term still see 15% growth and with a PE of 15 and earnings of 4 $ a fair price would be 60$. Probably not going to happen -- probably stuck with pe of 10 as growth seems to be slowing ( maybe communities outside Texas don't sell as well). So a fair price would be $40 one year from now. I think there will be opportunity to buy in at a lower price in the next month or two as slower growth becomes more evident. complicating factor are the large funds who want to buy shares in the company which seem to be multiplying -- they cause gyrations in both directions and make this more common sense approach quite difficult at times. Somebody tell me what I am missing.

Earnings this year will be a little over $7/share so we are trading at 11 times past earnings. Likely 2020 earnings will be about $8.00 maybe $8.20 but Use $.00 for simplicity. Homebuilders do not get a market multiple because of their cyclical nature, but the growth of this stock in sales and earnings consistently over the past 4-5 years should earn it a multiple of something like 13-14 which would indicate a price of $110.00 per share.

We hit 150 today, I was a little too conservative about this stock a few weeks ago. looks like we will hit 170-180 before the Summer starts. With the earning estimates, next year will be something like $2, 3, 3, 6. These will give us aTotal of $14 for the whole year. Apply a PE of 14, the share price should be somewhere around $200 by the end of next February. I believe we will hit $2 on the next earning report which is scheduled around May 7, 2021.

This is a crazy business and I've been spooked out this stock in the past by massive falls I could not understand. also, how would one compare this company to MHO? Smaller company but seems to be growing also.

Time for a little reflection on this years expectations. I cut and pasted from their press release but I cut out the disclaimers etc.disclaimer…..the Company offers the following guidance for 2020. The Company believes it will have between 120 and 130 active selling communities at the end of 2020 and close between 8,400 and 9,400 homes in 2020. In addition, the Company believes 2020 gross margin as a percentage of home sales revenues will be in the range of 22.5% and 24.5% and 2020 adjusted gross margin (non-GAAP) as a percentage of home sales revenues will be in the range of 24.5% and 26.5% with capitalized interest accounting for substantially all of the difference between gross margin and adjusted gross margin. The Company also believes that the average home sales price in 2020 will be between $235,000 and $245,000. This outlook assumes that general economic conditions, including interest rates and mortgage availability, in the remainder of 2020 are similar to those experienced so far in the first quarter of 2020 and that average home sales price, construction costs, availability of land, land development costs and overall absorption rates in the remainder of 2020 are consistent with the Company’s recent experience.Of course the pandemic hit and it obviously had short term and long term effects. Let’s see how they are doing or have done versus this initial guidance from the 2019 final year Press Release.120 – 130 active communities predicted and as of Dec 10th it looks like 115 so right on the mid range at least.8400-9400 homes predicted vs. 8800-9200 in the Dec 3 guidance which I think is sandbagged and will be a little over 9200 which would be near the high end of initial guidance.On gross margins they predicted 22.5 – 24.5 and adjusted of 24.5 – 26.5Through 9 months they were right on the high end of both gross margin predictions.They really missed the average selling price. They predicted 235-245K and actual through 9 months is $248K and will likely be about $250K by the end of the year.So my thoughts are even with the pandemic they have achieved or exceeded the high end of guidance (which I assume and hope they sandbag a little every year. )Looks pretty strong to me. Earnings will be impressive.

The headlines tell us that home sales are down for the last several months. Strangely, home builder stocks, including LGIH go down with that news. Seems to me that the home builders should have a long green road ahead --- once they get out of the rut.

Here is how I get that. Take last years revenue and add 3.1% for the increase in number of homes sold. I just dipped my toe in the water. Been watching this for a while and with earnings of $6-7 as the latest estimate they are trading at a p/e below 10. Keep in mind that the $6-7 provided is based on home closings of 6,000 - 7,000. Well guess what, through April they've already closed on over 3k homes (1,244 as reported in Q1 + another 1,850 in April as reported 1 week ago). That means they have 9 months to double what they've done in 3 months in order to hit the $6-7 estimate. My guess is that this is management conservatism and they will blow away the full year numbers.

LGIH should stop guidance altogether because they are very bad at it. I mean they as much admit that the guidance they give has nothing to do with the way the business is going or the way they see it.here is a quote from the transcript from the CEO"We want to be shocked if we don't produce great numbers in the third and fourth quarter, but that's not how we give guidance." So they give the news that would be bad enough to be shockingly bad to them as what they expect. Unless the world is falling down around you, it is reasonable to assume things will be better than this "shocking" level.I have been on a few BOD's and have seen this philosophy and in my opinion it is not the way to manage a business . It is vert transparent what they are doing but the financial analysts are really just a bunch of lemmings/hacks that do not see clearly enough to see what the MO of the low guidance every year by management. is here. For example with the blowout earnings they showed this week only 1 of 7 analysts have updated their expectations and at the low end they are predicting a very significant drop in EPS in the upcoming quarters. The low end expects earnings of just over $5 the last half while last year they made $8. So they expect with the hot market they are in (and you know July already has a strong month of 930 units at record breaking prices and Gross margin, with at least the next several months locked in vat that level. If you look at history it is clearly obvious that the low level of guidance is what they do all the time the analysts never like it, the stock drops at the Q meeting and then gains ground when everyone realizes the numbers are really pretty great.
